questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of a painful, red, and swollen eyelids bilaterally for the past three days. The patient reports that he has a gritty sensation in both eyes and crusting along his eyelashes. He has no pain with eye movements or vision changes, and he has not had a fever. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. He drinks alcohol socially and does not use tobacco products. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings shown in the image below, which are present on both eyes. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is no discharge or pain with extraocular eye movements. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with blepharitis, which is a chronic condition characterized by inflammation of the eyelid and associated eye irritation. First-line treatment includes warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing.     

Patients with blepharitis typically present with chronic irritation of both eyes, a gritty or burning sensation in both eyes, tearing, and crusting or matting of the eyelashes in the morning. Examination may reveal eyelid swelling and erythema. The eyelid edges often appear pink or irritated and crusting of the lashes or lid margins may be visible. There may be diffuse conjunctival injection.   

Aside from orbital cellulitis, which requires aggressive treatment with intravenous antibiotics, most eyelid disorders including blepharitis, can be treated with supportive and symptomatic management. For example, most cases of hordeolum, chalazion, and blepharitis will often resolve with warm compresses alone and only require additional treatment if refractory to initial therapy. Good eyelid hygiene is also important, including washing the lid with diluted baby shampoo, removing scales and debris, and avoiding eye makeup. Lid massage can help empty the eyelid glands and improve secretion. For blepharitis, topical antibiotics and steroids are reserved for severe or refractory cases.    

Option Analysis

✅ Warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Botulinum toxin injection:
Incorrect: Botulinum toxin injection can be utilized for recurrent blepharospasm; however, it is not indicated in the management of uncomplicated blepharitis.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is a first-line treatment for patients with peri-orbital or pre-septal cellulitis. This condition presents with pronounced swelling, tenderness and erythema of the peri-orbital soft tissues, and often fever—which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Steroid injection:
Incorrect: A steroid injection is appropriate for the treatment of a chalazion that is refractory to conservative therapy with warm compresses. It is not indicated in the management of blepharitis.  
❌ Check lipid panel :
Incorrect: A lipid panel would be appropriate in the evaluation of xanthelasma palpebrarum, a benign condition characterized by the development of soft, semisolid, yellow papules or plaques containing cholesterol that typically form over the eyelid. However, the exam findings for this patient are more consistent with blepharitis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of gradual loss of peripheral vision over the past year. He reports difficulty seeing objects that are in his peripheral vision while driving, and he has difficulty navigating in dimly lit environments. He does not have eye pain, redness, or sudden changes in vision. His medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, visual acuity is normal. Peripheral vision is decreased minimally. There is no conjunctival erythema, and the pupils are equal round and reactive to light. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. Fundoscopy reveals optic disc cupping with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7 bilaterally. Gonioscopy shows a wide anterior chamber angle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with open-angle glaucoma, including gradual peripheral vision loss, elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), and optic disc cupping on fundoscopy. The wide anterior chamber angle observed on gonioscopy supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate initial treatment for open-angle glaucoma is topical prostaglandin analogs (e.g. latanoprost), which increase the outflow of aqueous humor and lower intraocular pressure, helping to prevent optic nerve damage.       

Treatment for open-angle glaucoma focuses on lowering IOP to prevent further optic nerve damage. First-line treatment includes topical medications, such as prostaglandin analogs, which increase aqueous humor outflow, and beta-blockers, which reduce aqueous humor production. Laser trabeculoplasty may be performed to enhance drainage and may be used first line as well. For patients with advanced disease, surgical options like trabeculectomy or the placement of drainage devices may be considered.       

In contrast, acute angle-closure glaucoma is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention to rapidly reduce IOP. Initial treatment includes intravenous medications, such as mannitol or acetazolamide, and topical agents, like beta-blockers and alpha-2 agonists. Definitive treatment involves laser peripheral iridotomy or surgical iridectomy to relieve the blockage via creation of a new drainage pathway for aqueous humor, thereby preventing recurrent episodes and preserving vision. For patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma, the untreated opposite eye has a 40-80% risk of developing the condition within five to ten years, so prophylactic laser peripheral iridotomy is recommended for the unaffected eye.   

Option Analysis

❌ Surgical trabeculectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical therapy is used initially only in cases of severe peripheral field loss, or it can be used as second line therapy for patients who do not respond to medications or laser therapy. This patient should be treated with topical medication before considering surgery. 
❌ Intravenous mannitol:
Incorrect: Intravenous mannitol is used in emergency situations to rapidly lower intraocular pressure in patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma. It is not appropriate management for chronic open-angle glaucoma.  
❌ Mechanical shunt:
Incorrect: Shunts are typically placed only in patients with advanced disease who have had inadequate response to laser and medical therapy. This patient should be treated with topical medication before considering a shunt placement. 
❌ Iridectomy:
Incorrect: Iridectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat angle-closure glaucoma by creating a new drainage pathway for aqueous humor. This patient has open-angle glaucoma. 
✅ Topical prostaglandin analogs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman arrives at the primary care physician for evaluation of headaches and blurry vision, which began five months ago. The symptoms are worse in the morning and progressively improve over the course of the day. Past medical history is notable for acne vulgaris. The patient currently takes oral contraceptive pills and doxycycline. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. The neurological examination is nonfocal and there is no nuchal rigidity. A Fundoscopy is performed and reveals findings similar to the ones shown below. MRI imaging is noncontributory. A lumbar puncture is performed and the opening pressure is 260 mmH2O. The patient is noted to have immediate relief of her headache following the procedure. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has headaches, blurry vision, papilledema, and an elevated opening pressure in the setting of oral contraceptive and tetracycline use (e.g. doxycycline). She most likely has idiopathic intracranial hypertension (also termed pseudotumor cerebri).    

The first-line medication for treating idiopathic intracranial hypertension is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI). Examples from this medication class include acetazolamide and brinzolamide. CAIs inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which can be found in the choroid plexus of the brain, proximal convoluted tubules of the kidney, and ciliary bodies of the eye. As a result, CAIs can reduce the rate of cerebrospinal fluid production, thereby improving the symptoms of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  

CAIs can also be used to treat glaucoma by reducing aqueous humor production, mountain sickness by inducing a metabolic acidosis, as well as pulmonary edema and ascites via increasing urine output.   

Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of methylprednisolone therapy:
Incorrect: In the short-term, corticosteroids can quickly reduce intracranial pressure in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. However, in the long-term, corticosteroids can cause weight gain, which would further exacerbate symptoms. As a result, corticosteroids are generally avoided in the management of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  
❌ Placement of ventriculoperitoneal shunt:
Incorrect: A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt can help drain excess cerebrospinal fluid. It is effective in reducing headaches and less effective for correcting visual disturbances. However, medical interventions to treat the patient’s idiopathic intracranial hypertension should be attempted first before proceeding to surgery.  
❌ Administration of mannitol:
Incorrect: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It can treat cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure by decreasing brain volume and its overall water content. However, mannitol’s efficacy in treating idiopathic intracranial hypertension is not as well documented as that of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.   
❌ Perform optic nerve sheath fenestration:
Incorrect: An optic nerve sheath fenestration involves making slits in the optic nerve. This procedure decompresses the nerve and helps relieve vision-related symptoms arising secondary to idiopathic intracranial hypertension. However, medical interventions should be attempted first before proceeding to surgery.  
✅ Administration of acetazolamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a one-day history of severe left eye pain and blurred vision accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and headache. Three days ago, the patient visited his primary care physician and was prescribed a nasal decongestant for sinus congestion. Past medical history is significant for migraine, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and schizophrenia. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased visual acuity. The left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated fixed pupil. The left eye is stony-hard in texture. The rest of the neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with sudden onset, unilateral eye pain and ipsilateral headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision, combined with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG), most likely precipitated by pseudoephedrine (a sympathomimetic drug). Pseudoephedrine is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist, which can induce angle closure by mydriasis and diminished outflow of aqueous humor.

Anything causing pupillary dilatation can trigger an acute attack. Topical or systemic parasympatholytic agents (mydriatics, antihistamines), sympathomimetics (epinephrine, pseudoephedrine), dim illumination, and emotionally upsetting events have all been used been implicated as precipitating factors. Critically ill patients treated for respiratory failure with nebulized β-sympathomimetic and anticholinergic medications (e.g., albuterol and ipratropium) may develop AACG.

Management of ACCG involves medical control of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) via timolol, apraclonidine, pilocarpine, or acetazolamide, followed by a reversal of angle-closure by laser peripheral iridotomy or other surgical treatments. The patient should be referred urgently to an ophthalmologist for care.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute migraine attack:
Incorrect: Acute migraine attack is characterized by a disabling headache associated with nausea and light and sound sensitivity. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
✅ Medication-induced mydriasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eye dehydration secondary to lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and is the first-line medication for hypertension. It is unlikely to cause eye dehydration and precipitate angle-closure glaucoma as seen in this patient.  
❌ Bacterial conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by mild ocular pain. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Optic neuritis:
Incorrect: Optic neuritis is characterized by a sudden loss of vision (partial or complete), sudden blurred or "foggy" vision, and pain on movement of the affected eye, and can be seen in certain demyelinating diseases (e.g. multiple sclerosis). A fixed, mid-dilated pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for headache and right eye pain. The symptoms started two days ago and have progressively worsened. The patient reports photosensitivity and sees a halo around lights. She has constant nausea and has vomited three times today. There has been no recent head trauma. Her past medical history includes migraines, for which she takes sumatriptan; however, this medication has not improved her current symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 134/82 mmHg. Vision is 20/30 in the left eye and 20/70 in the right eye. Physical examination reveals dilation of the right pupil, which is non-reactive, and conjunctival injection (see the image below). Examination of the left eye is within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis? 


Image by James Heilman, MD is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiCommons

choices.text: Angle between the iris and cornea of ≤ 20 degrees

questions.solution:
This patient’s eye pain, blurred vision, headache with nausea, and eye findings are concerning for acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is an ocular emergency. A gonioscopy exam that reveals an angle between the iris and cornea of ≤ 20 degrees confirms the diagnosis.        

The diagnostic workup for a patient presenting with a red eye varies depending on key features that suggest either an emergent or non-emergent process. Emergent, vision-threatening conditions, such as angle-closure glaucoma, globe rupture, scleritis, uveitis, keratitis, corneal injury, and hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis, should be considered when red-flag features are present. Red flag features include severe pain, decreased visual acuity, photophobia, pupillary changes, increased intraocular pressure, anterior chamber inflammation, and corneal epithelial defects. Additional diagnostic workup in consultation with an ophthalmologist should be pursued when red flag features are present.        

In acute angle-closure glaucoma, gonioscopy can assess the angle between the iris and cornea, tonometry will reveal increased intraocular pressure, and both fundoscopy and slit lamp examination will show a shallow anterior chamber and an enlarged optic cup. Uveitis is another emergent condition which is confirmed when a slit lamp examination reveals a collection of white blood cells layered within the anterior chamber and a hazy appearance of the aqueous humor due to an increased concentration of protein. If local tenderness, a teardrop-shaped pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber are present, there should be concern for globe rupture. Lastly, a slit lamp exam revealing inflamed scleral vessels indicates scleritis.   



Option Analysis

✅ Angle between the iris and cornea of ≤ 20 degrees:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intraocular pressure of 20 mmHg:
Incorrect: Tonometry values of up to 21 mmHg are considered normal. This patient most likely has acute angle closure glaucoma and would have a tonometry measurement of intraocular pressure >21 mmHg. 
❌ Inflammation of meibomian glands:
Incorrect: Inflammation of meibomian glands can lead to dry eyes and is a common finding in conditions like blepharitis. It is not typically seen in acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Positive Schirmer test:
Incorrect: A positive Schirmer test is noted when less than 10 millimeters of tear production is measured on a filter paper placed between the lower lid of the eye and the conjunctiva. It indicates keratoconjunctivitis sicca, which is a benign cause of a red eye. This patient's findings are more consistent with acute angle closure glaucoma, which can be confirmed by measurement of the Angle between the iris and cornea of ≤ 20 degrees 
❌ Cobblestone papillae under the eyelid:
Incorrect: Cobblestone papillae under the eyelid is a sign of giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC), which is an allergic process. This patient's findings are more consistent with acute angle closure glaucoma, which can be confirmed by a measurement of the Angle between the iris and cornea of ≤ 20 degrees

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of bilateral eye redness, and yellow /white discharge from both eyes for the past three days. He does not have eye pain, photophobia, or decreased visual acuity. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. On physical examination, Pupils are equal, round, reactive to light. There is bilateral conjunctival injection and thin yellow/white discharge, extra ocular muscles are intact bilaterally. There is no ciliary flush or photophobia. There is clear liquid from both nostrils and pharyngeal erythema without tonsillar swelling or exudates. Mildly tender cervical lymphadenopathy is noted bilaterally. Which of the following additional historical elements is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Use of new eye drops containing preservatives
Recent post-nasal drip and sore throat

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of bilateral eye redness, and yellow/white discharge, along with findings of rhinorrhea, pharyngeal erythema and cervical lymphadenopathy is consistent with viral upper respiratory tract infection and viral conjunctivitis. Viral conjunctivitis is commonly caused by adenoviruses and often follows an upper respiratory infection which may present with postnasal drip, sore throat, rhinorrhea, fever, and cough.        

Another common cause of conjunctivitis is bacterial conjunctivitis, which typically presents with conjunctival erythema with mucopurulent discharge, eyelid matting, and a foreign body sensation in one or both eyes. Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis, often caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is characterized by copious purulent discharge, severe pain, and decreased vision. Patients may have a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, a weakened immune system, or it can be seen in neonates after vaginal delivery. Allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral itchiness, burning eyes, and watery discharge, often associated with signs of allergic rhinitis; patients will typically have a history of environmental allergies such as pollen or pet dander. Chemical conjunctivitis results from exposure to irritants like household cleaners, leading to eye pain, redness, and blurred vision. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, or dry eye disease, is associated with chronic dryness and a foreign body sensation in both eyes, often seen in patients with Sjogren syndrome or those taking medications with a drying effect (e.g., anticholinergics, antihistamines).        



Option Analysis

❌ Recent unprotected sexual intercourse :
Incorrect: Recent unprotected sexual intercourse is more likely associated with hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis, which is often caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Patients with this condition typically present with abrupt onset of copious purulent discharge associated with pain and blurry vision.  
❌ Use of new eye drops containing preservatives:
Incorrect: Use of new eye drops containing preservatives could suggest a chemical or allergic conjunctival reaction, which would present as itchy, burning eyes, in a patient with a history of allergies. Rhinorrhea, Pharyngeal erythema, and lymphadenopathy are more suggestive of a viral illness with viral conjunctivitis.  
❌ Recent exposure to household cleaners:
Incorrect: A recent exposure to household cleaners could suggest a chemical conjunctival reaction, which would present as eye pain, with or without decreased visual acuity and possibly eyelid edema. This patient’s findings of rhinorrhea, pharyngeal erythema, and lymphadenopathy are more suggestive of a viral illness with viral conjunctivitis.  
❌ Frequent dry mouth:
Incorrect: Frequent dry mouth is associated with Sjogren syndrome, which can cause keratoconjunctivitis sicca, which typically presents with photophobia and a foreign body sensation in both eyes. This patient’s findings of rhinorrhea, pharyngeal erythema, and lymphadenopathy are more suggestive of a viral illness with viral conjunctivitis. 
✅ Recent post-nasal drip and sore throat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of mild discomfort in his eyes. The patient is unsure of the onset. His vision remains unchanged. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Ophthalmological examination reveals increased intraocular pressure. Mental status and neurological examination are within normal limits. After discussing treatment options, the patient is initiated on timolol eye drops. This medication will improve this patient’s symptoms via the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with ocular discomfort and increased intraocular pressure most likely have open-angle glaucoma. Glaucoma is an optic neuropathy characterized by an increased intraocular pressure associated with increased aqueous humor production or decreased aqueous humor outflow. The patient is initiated on topical timolol, which is a beta-blocker used to treat glaucoma and acts to decrease the activity of Gα subunit receptors on the ciliary body and lead to decreased aqueous humor production. Glaucoma medications are summarized above.

In addition to medications, laser treatments are also available and includes:

  • Trabeculoplasty: a laser is used to open the trabecular mesh network which helps treat open-angle glaucoma.
  • Iridotomy is a laser used to punch a tiny hole in the iris, which helps treat closed-angle glaucoma.
Other laser treatments destroy the humor-producing cells, which reduces the production of the fluid, and in severe cases, sometimes they can be used to create a new channel through which the aqueous humor can be drained out.

On the other hand, implants shunt fluid out of the anterior chamber by bypassing the trabecular meshwork and collecting system.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Decrease aqueous humor synthesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase uveoscleral outflow:
Incorrect: Topical prostaglandins (e.g. latanoprost) increases the aqueous humor outflow via the uveoscleral pathway. Timolol is a beta-blocker.  
❌ Decrease retinal neovascularization:
Incorrect: Incropen-angulation of new blood vessels at the optic disc is the characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. Strict glycemic control, rather than a topical beta-blocker, decreases the risk of diabetic retinopathy. Additional therapies for reducing retinal neovascularization include intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, such as bevacizumab.  
❌ Ciliary muscle contraction:
Incorrect: Muscarinic agonists (e.g. pilocarpine) increase the outflow of aqueous humor via the contraction of the ciliary muscle and opening of the trabecular meshwork.  
❌ Increases trabecular outflow:
Incorrect: Muscarinic agonists (e.g. pilocarpine) increase the aqueous humor's outflow via the trabecular meshwork's ciliary muscle contraction and opening.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset, severe left-sided eye pain, and ipsilateral headache. The patient also reports nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type two diabetes mellitus, both currently being medically managed. The patient started taking phenylephrine for nasal congestion for two days. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased visual acuity. The left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated fixed pupil. The left eye is stony and hard in texture.  Gonioscopy shows that the iris meets the cornea at an angle of 10° (N = 20–45°). Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with sudden onset, unilateral eye pain and ipsilateral headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision, in combination with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and decreased iridocorneal angle on gonioscopy, is consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma (ACG). It is characterized by narrowing or closure of the anterior chamber angle, leading to inadequate drainage of the aqueous humor, increased intraocular pressure (IOP), and subsequent damage to the optic nerve. It was most likely triggered in this patient by recent phenylephrine use, which is a sympathomimetic and causes pupillary dilation, narrowing the anterior chamber.

Oral or intravenous carbonic anhydrase (CA) inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide, and brinzolamide) are effective treatment options for ACG. It works by inhibiting CA, which is found in the ciliary body epithelium. Inhibition of CA reduces the formation of bicarbonate ions, which reduces fluid transport and thus reduces IOP. Side effects include paraesthesia, drowsiness, metallic taste, abdominal cramps, polyuria, metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte changes (hypokalemia, hyponatremia). Topical CA inhibitors can be used in the management of open-angle glaucoma.

Intravenous mannitol (diuretic) is also sometimes used to treat acute glaucoma. It dehydrates the vitreous humor and, therefore, lowers the IOP. Adverse effects include hyponatremia and volume depletion leading to metabolic acidosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Topical atropine:
Incorrect: Topical atropine is used to facilitate pupillary dilation during a retinal examination. It should be avoided in acute angle-closure glaucoma because the dilation can lead to angle narrowing and decreased flow of aqueous humor to the anterior chamber and further worsens the symptoms.  
✅ Intravenous acetazolamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral triptans:
Incorrect: Oral triptans are the treatment of choice for acute migraine attacks. It is characterized by a disabling headache generally associated with nausea and light and sound sensitivity. The cornea is clear and pupillary size, and response to light is normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Topical moxifloxacin:
Incorrect: Topical moxifloxacin is the treatment of choice for bacterial conjunctivitis. It is characterized by mild ocular pain. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Topical ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Topical ganciclovir can be used to manage infectious keratitis caused by herpes simplex, characterized by red eyes, photophobia, foreign body sensation, and watery discharge. Pupillary size and response to light are normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office to check up. The patient feels well, aside from the occasional headache and frequent falls. The rest of the history is unremarkable. The patient has a past medical history of type II  diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Fundoscopy reveals thinning of the optic disc rim and asymmetry of the cup/disc ratio between the eyes. The rest of the neurological exam is within normal limits. A diagnosis of open-angle glaucoma is established. The patient asks the physician about topical pilocarpine that his brother has been using for the same condition. This medication will help treat open-angle glaucoma via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Decreased secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium
Ciliary muscle contraction and increased trabecular outflow
​Decreased aqueous secretion due to lack of HCO3–

questions.solution:
Topical pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist that can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma (OAG).

Cholinergic agonists (e.g., pilocarpine, carbachol) lower the intraocular pressure (IOP) by causing muscarinic-induced contraction of the ciliary muscle, which facilitates aqueous outflow via the trabecular meshwork. They do not affect aqueous production. Pilocarpine is very effective at opening meshwork into the canal of Schlemm and can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Ciliary body spasm is a muscarinic cholinergic effect that can induce myopia and refraction due to iris and ciliary body contraction. The drug effect waxes and wanes between doses. Headaches can also occur from the iris and ciliary body contraction. The ocular side effects have decreased the utilization of these drugs, and they are not typically first-line medications used in OAG.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol. betaxolol, and carvedilol) are an effective treatment option for glaucoma. It decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium.  
❌ Increased aqueous humor uveoscleral outflow:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost and bimatoprost) increase the outflow of aqueous humor by decreasing the resistance of flow through the uveoscleral pathway.  
✅ Ciliary muscle contraction and increased trabecular outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ​Decreased aqueous secretion due to lack of HCO3–:
Incorrect:  Carbonic anhydrase (CA) inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide, and brinzolamide) are effective treatment options for glaucoma. It works by inhibiting CA, which is found in the ciliary body epithelium, thus inhibiting aqueous humor formation due to lack of HCO3–.  
❌ Removal of water from eye:
Incorrect: Intravenous mannitol (diuretic) is also sometimes used to treat acute glaucoma. It dehydrates the vitreous humor and, therefore, lowers the intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral eye pain, which has been ongoing for the past 2 weeks. The pain was initially described as a “sand in my eyes” feeling, but it has now progressed to sharp, stabbing pain. The patient previously used artificial tears, but now they provide minimal symptomatic relief. In addition, the patient has been experiencing dryness in the mouth and joint pain in the fingers. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/83 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. There is bilateral conjunctival injection. The oral mucosal membranes are dry. A Shirmer test is performed and reveals decreased tear production. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves tear and saliva production. Several days later, the patient begins experiencing shortness of breath and wheezing. Which medication was she most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dry eyes (due to decreased tear production), dry mouth, and joint pain. These findings are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome (SS), a chronic multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the lacrimal and salivary glands that results in dry eyes and mouth. This patient was most likely treated with systemic pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic that stimulates secretions from the lacrimal and salivary glands. Pilocarpine also acts on the bronchial smooth muscles, causing bronchospasm in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Cholinomimetics (e.g., bethanechol, carbachol, pilocarpine) have no absolute contraindications. However, since they cause bronchospasms, they should be avoided in individuals with COPD and asthma. Moreover, they increase gastric acid secretion and should be avoided in individuals with peptic ulcer disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pilocarpine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ipratropium:
Incorrect: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic medication used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Ipratropium is unlikely to exacerbate COPD symptoms.  
❌ Mirabegron:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics such as mirabegron act on the β3-receptor to cause relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle, which leads to increased bladder capacity. Mirabegron is used in the management of urinary incontinence, but has no role in increasing tear or saliva production. Moreover, it does cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Miconazole:
Incorrect: Miconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat oral candidiasis. Although this patient has a dry mouth, there is no evidence of a fungal infection. Moreover, miconazole does not cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Bethanechol:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic agent that can be administered to stimulate intestinal motility in patients with ileus or bladder contractility and emptying in patients with urinary retention. Bethanechol is not typically used in the production of tears and saliva. Therefore, it is unlikely this patient was prescribed bethanechol.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic because of sudden onset severe left eye pain, associated with headache and nausea. She describes the pain as intense, throbbing, and accompanied by blurry vision and seeing halos around lights. She has a history of hyperopia (farsightedness). Vitals are within normal limits. Visual acuity is decreased in the left eye compared to the right. On physical examination of the left eye, there is marked diffuse conjunctival injection, the cornea appears hazy, and the pupil is dilated and nonreactive. Examination of the right eye is within normal limits. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Topical beta-blockers and follow-up in 24 hours
Oral acetazolamide and follow-up in 48 hours
Topical prostaglandin analogs and referral to ophthalmologist
Transfer to emergency department for urgent ophthalmology consultation

questions.solution:
The patient presents with signs, symptoms, and examination findings that are highly suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG). AACG is considered an ophthalmologic emergency. This patient should be sent to the emergency department for urgent ophthalmology consultation and treatment.        

The sudden and severe onset of eye pain, along with associated symptoms like headache, nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances (such as blurry vision and seeing halos around lights) as seen in this patient are strongly suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Examination findings of a hazy cornea and a dilated, non-reactive pupil support this diagnosis. An additional finding associated with acute angle closure glaucoma would be significantly elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).         

The primary goal in managing AACG is to rapidly reduce IOP using medications such as intravenous or oral acetazolamide, along with topical agents like beta-blockers or alpha-2 agonists. IV mannitol may also be considered. Once the IOP is lowered, an emergent laser peripheral iridotomy is typically performed to create an alternative drainage pathway for aqueous humor, preventing recurrence of the angle closure and preserving vision.  



Option Analysis

❌ Topical beta-blockers and follow-up in 24 hours:
Incorrect: Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmic emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent permanent vision loss. Outpatient treatment with topical beta-blockers alone is insufficient and can result in irreversible optic nerve damage and vision loss. 
❌ Oral acetazolamide and follow-up in 48 hours:
Incorrect: Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmic emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent permanent vision loss. Outpatient treatment with acetazolamide alone is insufficient and can result in irreversible optic nerve damage and vision loss. 
❌ Referral to ophthalmologist :
Incorrect: Outpatient evaluation is not appropriate for patients with acute angle closure glaucoma. This patient requires immediate ophthalmologic intervention and should be seen in the emergency department for treatment and ophthalmology consultation. 
❌ Topical prostaglandin analogs and referral to ophthalmologist:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin analogs can be used in the treatment of glaucoma, but acute closed angle glaucoma is an emergent condition requiring emergency care and an urgent ophthalmology consultation. 
✅ Transfer to emergency department for urgent ophthalmology consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of gradual loss of peripheral vision in both eyes over the past several months. He also notes difficulty adjusting to changes in light intensity and glare, particularly while driving at night. He does not have eye pain, nausea, or vomiting. Medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, visual acuity is normal bilaterally, and there is no redness or cloudiness of either eye. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and findings suggestive of open-angle glaucoma, which is a chronic progressive condition that can result in optic nerve damage. Gradual loss of peripheral vision, elevated intraocular pressure, and absence of pain suggest open-angle glaucoma. Optic disc cupping is a hallmark finding on fundoscopy, reflecting the loss of optic nerve fibers and an increased cup-to-disc ratio, which is characteristic of the disease.        

A thorough history and physical examination can help distinguish between acute angle-closure glaucoma and open-angle glaucoma. Acute angle-closure glaucoma is a medical emergency that presents with sudden onset severe eye pain, redness, and significant elevation of intraocular pressure. Patients often experience additional symptoms, including headache, nausea, and blurry vision, and require immediate treatment to prevent permanent vision loss. In contrast, open-angle glaucoma develops gradually and is usually painless with patients experiencing a slow, progressive loss of peripheral vision.    



Option Analysis

❌ Flame-shaped hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are typically seen in conditions such as hypertensive retinopathy and associated retinal vascular disorders. They are not characteristic of open-angle glaucoma, which primarily affects the optic nerve rather than retinal blood vessels and is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms. 
❌ Drusen deposits:
Incorrect: Drusen deposits are yellowish extracellular material found in the macula, typically associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). They are not associated with open angle glaucoma. 
❌ Cherry-red spot:
Incorrect: A cherry-red spot is a finding associated with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) and metabolic storage diseases like Tay-Sachs disease. It is not related to glaucoma, which involves optic nerve damage rather than retinal arterial occlusion. 
❌ Macular edema:
Incorrect: Macular edema is associated with diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion, and other conditions that affect the macula. Open-angle glaucoma, on the other hand, typically causes optic nerve damage without involving the macula. 
✅ Optic disc cupping:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male infant is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of purulent discharge from both eyes for the past day. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery at home. He has been breastfed exclusively. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral conjunctival injection, purulent discharge from the eyes, and associated edema of the upper and lower eyelids. Which of the following medications is used to prevent this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This neonate, recently born at home, is presenting with purulent eye discharge and bilateral eyelid swelling, consistent with gonococcal conjunctivitis. Application of ophthalmic erythromycin is routinely applied at birth to prevent the development of this condition.  

Neonates are at higher risk of conjunctivitis due to decreased tear production, lack of IgA in tears, poor native immune function, and absence of lymphoid tissue in conjunctiva. Neonatal conjunctivitis, also called ophthalmia neonatorum, typically presents during the first four weeks of life and is usually acquired from the mother (as the patient passes through the birth canal) or following the application of chemical agents.    

The age of the neonate is an important clue towards determining the etiology of neonatal conjunctivitis:  
  •  First 24 hrs of life: Chemical causes from prophylactic medications, such as silver nitrate drops (now rarely used because of the increased risk of chemical conjunctivitis) or erythromycin drops for gonococcal conjunctivitis 
  •  24 - 48 hrs of life: Bacterial causes are most likely (Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause in the time range, Staphylococcus aureus).  
  •  5 - 14 days of life: Chlamydia trachomatis  
  •  6 - 14 days of life: Herpes keratoconjunctivitis  


Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic erythromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous acyclovir:
Incorrect: Intravenous acyclovir is an effective treatment for neonatal herpes simplex infection, which instead presents with excessive watery discharge from the eyes, eye pain, and conjunctival erythema. If untreated, patients can develop irreversible vision impairment or blindness. 
❌ Intravenous ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is an effective treatment for patients with cytomegalovirus (CMV)-induced retinitis. This neonates patient’s presentation, however, is more consistent with bacterial conjunctivitis. 
❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Intravenous ceftriaxone is an appropriate treatment for gonococcal conjunctivitis, but it would not have prevented the condition even if given initially at the time of delivery. 
❌ Ophthalmic levofloxacin :
Incorrect: Ophthalmic levofloxacin is useful in patients presenting with bacterial conjunctivitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Haemophilus influenzae. It is not useful against N. gonorrhoeae, nor is it used prophylactically in the prevention of gonococcal conjunctivitis.
❌ Oral erythromycin :
Incorrect: Oral erythromycin is the preferred treatment for neonatal C. trachomatis infections, including both conjunctivitis and pneumonia. C. trachomatis typically presents 5-14 days after birth with mucopurulent discharge, as opposed to this neonate’s discharge which is purulent. Additionally, oral erythromycin is not used for prophylaxis of gonococcal conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of left eye swelling for five days and one day of fever. Parent reports the patient hit his eye on a door handle 5 days ago, and since that time, it has had progressively worsening swelling, and today he developed a fever. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), blood pressure is 110/67mmHg, pulse is 111/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has erythema, swelling of the left upper and lower eyelids, and tenderness around the orbit. There is no bruising around the eye and the left cheek is not flattened. Conjunctiva is normal bilaterally, but the left eye has reduced visual acuity. There is marked pain in the left eye with extraocular movements. The right eye and eyelids are within normal limits. Tympanic membranes are normal bilaterally. Which of the following complications could result if the underlying condition is not identified and treated appropriately?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with several concerning features of orbital cellulitis including orbital swelling, erythema, and tenderness about the orbit. Pain with extraocular eye movements indicates increased intraorbital pressure, differentiating this condition from preseptal periorbital cellulitis. Without recognition and acute treatment, this patient’s condition may progress, and he could develop an orbital abscess, subperiosteal abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or intracranial extension all of which could result in permanent vision loss.

Periorbital and orbital cellulitis are bacterial infections of the soft tissues within or around the orbit typically from Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and other gram-positive skin flora. The relation of the infection to the orbital septum and the presence or absence of increased intraorbital pressure can differentiate orbital from periorbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis occurs posterior to the orbital septum and is associated with increased intraorbital pressure, while periorbital cellulitis occurs in the soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum and is not associated with increased intraorbital pressure.

Patients with orbital cellulitis may present with signs of sepsis and should be stabilized accordingly with airway support and intravenous fluids. Acute management involves the administration of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, typically with a second or third-generation cephalosporin and urgent ophthalmology consultation. In contrast, patients with periorbital cellulitis commonly present with stable vital signs and can be treated with outpatient antibiotics.   

Option Analysis

✅ Subperiosteal abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Herniation of orbital contents:
Incorrect: Herniation of orbital contents is a sequelae of orbital floor fracture however this patient has no evidence of orbital floor fracture and has findings consistent with orbital cellulitis which if left untreated could result in orbital and subperiosteal abscess.
❌ Mastoiditis:
Incorrect: Mastoiditis is a known sequelae of otitis media, not orbital cellulitis. This patient's presentation is consistent with orbital cellulitis, placing this patient at risk of developing orbital and subperiosteal abscesses.
❌ Retinal detachment:
Incorrect: While untreated orbital cellulitis can lead to intracranial extension, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and vision loss, retinal detachment is not a known complication.
❌ Fungemia:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most commonly identified pathogens in orbital cellulitis. Fungal infection and subsequent fungemia are rare complications of this condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left eye pain and swelling for five days. The patient has no significant medical history and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 38.3 F°C (101°F), blood pressure is 111/72mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to person, place, and time and answers questions appropriately. There is soft tissue swelling and erythema around the left orbit with associated proptosis and chemosis. The patient has evidence of decreased visual acuity and ophthalmoplegia. The rest of the neurological exam is nonfocal. The patient is started on ceftriaxone and vancomycin. Ophthalmology is consulted. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) sinus and orbit with contrast
Apply warm compresses and discharge home

questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings concerning orbital cellulitis with severe features/complications. Notably, this patient has evidence of ophthalmoplegia and proptosis, both of which are indications for obtaining advanced imaging via CT to assess for the presence of an abscess and complicating deep space infection.

Periorbital cellulitis is caused by bacterial infection around the orbit while orbital cellulitis is caused by bacterial infection of the soft tissues within the orbit. Orbital cellulitis should be suspected when signs of increased orbital pressure are present such as blurred vision or reduced visual acuity, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, chemosis, and abnormal corneal light reflex. Patients with orbital cellulitis can also present with systemic signs and symptoms including fever and leukocytosis.

Once orbital cellulitis is diagnosed, patients should be assessed for features that indicate severe or complicated orbital cellulitis. These features include deteriorating visual acuity, gross proptosis, or ophthalmoplegia, as well as signs of central nervous system involvement, like focal neurologic deficits, seizures, and altered mental status. Patients who meet these criteria should have CT sinus and orbit with contrast to evaluate for deep space infection, specifically for orbital or subperiosteal abscesses.

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) sinus and orbit with contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: CT imaging should be pursued to assess for abscess formation and complications before surgical consultation.
❌ Switch vancomycin to linezolid:
Incorrect: Switching from vancomycin to linezolid is unnecessary as both provide adequate coverage for MRSA. CT imaging should be pursued to assess for abscess formation or other deep tissue infections.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: While intracranial extension of infection is a feared consequence of untreated orbital cellulitis, this patient has no signs of meningitis or encephalitis and should first undergo CT imaging to assess for deep space infection.
❌ Apply warm compresses and discharge home:
Incorrect: Warm compresses serve as the treatment for uncomplicated stye or hordeolum. This patient has evidence of orbital cellulitis and needs intravenous antibiotics, urgent ophthalmology consult, and CT imaging to rule out complications of orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left eye pain and swelling for one week. Parent is at the bedside and states that the patient sustained a bug bite to her lower eyelid that progressively increased in size over the past week. He became more concerned today when the patient developed a fever at home and began complaining of pain with eye movements. The patient has no significant medical history and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 38.3 F°C (101°F), blood pressure is 108/65mmHg, pulse is 117/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has evidence of soft tissue swelling erythema, tenderness around the left orbit, and pain with extraocular movements. She states her vision is blurry, but visual acuity testing is within normal limits. The rest of the neurological examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) sinus and orbit with contrast
Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and discharge home

questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with orbital cellulitis; including orbital erythema, swelling, tenderness, fever, pain with extraocular eye movements, and blurry vision. When orbital cellulitis is suspected, treatment involves the administration of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy targeting S. aureus (including methicillin-resistant S. aureus [MRSA]), S. pneumoniae, and other streptococci, gram-negative bacilli and possibly anaerobes. 3rd generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone plus vancomycin for coverage of MRS are appropriate, and ophthalmology should be consulted.

Preseptal, periorbital cellulitis is treated conservatively, using oral antibiotics with anti-beta-lactamase activity. Uncomplicated orbital cellulitis can be treated with intravenous vancomycin to cover for MRSA and a 3rd generation cephalosporin. Other regimens may also be appropriate. Anaerobic coverage may be added in certain circumstances. When severe or complicated orbital cellulitis is diagnosed, patients should undergo CT of the orbit and sinus with contrast and surgical evaluation for drainage of potential abscesses in addition to continued intravenous antibiotics.

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: This patient has no features concerning a deep space infection, so a surgical consultation is not indicated. If there was concern for an abscess or deep space infection, a CT should be obtained before surgical consultation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) sinus and orbit with contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has no features concerning a deep space infection or complicated orbital cellulitis. CT imaging is therefore not indicated.
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and discharge home:
Incorrect: This oral antibiotic regimen would not provide sufficient coverage for the treatment of orbital cellulitis. It may be used to treat periorbital cellulitis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics that provide coverage for S. aureus (including methicillin-resistant S. aureus [MRSA]), S. pneumoniae and other streptococci, gram-negative bacilli, and possibly anaerobes are recommended to treat orbital cellulitis.
❌ Topical erythromycin ointment and discharge:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics do not provide sufficient coverage for the treatment of orbital cellulitis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used that provide coverage of S. aureus (including methicillin-resistant S. aureus [MRSA]), S. pneumoniae and other streptococci, and gram-negative bacilli.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office by a parent for evaluation of an eye concern. The parent noticed that the child looks “crossed-eyed,” with the patient's left eye deviating inward compared to the right eye. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no daily medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity and red reflexes are normal bilaterally. Corneal light reflection and a cover-uncover test show no ocular misalignment. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?

choices.text: Blood within the vitreous body on fundoscopy

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old child presents with findings concerning for potential amblyopia. Normal corneal light reflection and a negative cover-uncover test indicate intact ocular alignment, making pseudostrabismus the likely diagnosis. This condition refers to the false perception of ocular malalignment caused by anatomical features. A flat, broad nasal bridge, prominent epicanthal folds, and a narrow interpupillary distance can create the illusion of true strabismus.        

Amblyopia, sometimes called “lazy eye,” is reduced visual acuity in one or both eyes that impairs normal visual cortex development. Early identification is essential to support proper ophthalmologic development. Common causes include strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), visual deprivation, and refractive error.        

Evaluation for amblyopia and strabismus begins with a history and physical examination, including visual acuity testing and red reflex testing. Most patients will have reduced visual acuity, but many remain asymptomatic with the condition detected by clear deviation of an eye on physical examination. When symptoms do occur, they may include blurry vision, vision loss, squinting, head tilt, or (in infants) a lack of eye contact.        

If no obvious ocular deviation is noted on history or examination, consider refractive or deprivation amblyopia and perform a complete eye examination with fundoscopy. If ocular deviation is suspected, the corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests can distinguish true strabismus from pseudostrabismus by assessing ocular alignment.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ptosis:
Incorrect: Ptosis, or upper eyelid droop, may accompany extraocular muscle weakness in cranial nerve III palsy, which would produce a “down and out” eye position and a positive cover test – neither of which are present in this vignette. 
✅ Flat, broad nasal bridge:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood within the vitreous body on fundoscopy:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage produces an abnormal red reflex (often dark or diminished) and usually impairs visual acuity. However, this patient has a normal red reflex and intact vision in the affected eye. 
❌ Papilledema:
Incorrect: Papilledema results from elevated intracranial pressure. When it is accompanied by an inwardly deviated eye, cranial nerve VI palsy should be suspected. However, this condition would produce persistent ocular misalignment on examination on cover-uncover testing, which is not present in this vignette. 
❌ Periorbital pain:
Incorrect: Normal visual acuity, a symmetric corneal light reflex, and a negative cover-uncover test indicate pseudostrabismus. Pain is not typical of pseudostrabismus but is more consistent with conditions such as periorbital cellulitis or trauma – neither of which is supported by the history or examination findings.

questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at 36 weeks’ gestation is evaluated in the nursery. The infant is small for gestational age. Prenatal care was inconsistent, but there is no history of drug use or teratogen exposure. The parent recalls having a “cold” early in the pregnancy and is unsure if she received her childhood vaccinations. Delivery was uneventful, and Apgar scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 42/min, blood pressure is 72/38 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, multiple violaceous macules are noted on the skin. No dysmorphic features are present. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous, machine-like murmur. Ophthalmologic evaluation shows a bilateral blue-grey pupillary reflex with lens opacities. Which of the following is the most probable cause of the ophthalmological findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn’s low birth weight, bilateral cataracts (blue-grey pupillary reflex with lens opacities), patent ductus arteriosus, and “blueberry-muffin” rash are most likely due to congenital rubella syndrome.

Congenital rubella syndrome results from maternal infection with rubella virus in the first trimester of pregnancy. It typically presents with congenital heart defects (commonly patent ductus arteriosus), sensorineural hearing loss, a petechial or "blueberry muffin" rash from dermal extramedullary hematopoiesis, and cataracts.  

In patients presenting with leukocoria, an ophthalmologic examination provides essential information to guide the diagnosis. If no intraocular mass is detected, the next step is to evaluate for lens opacities, which indicate cataracts. A thorough history can then help identify the underlying cause. Etiologies to consider include prematurity, metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and congenital infections. In older children, trauma or chronic corticosteroid use may be factors. Persistent fetal vasculature is another potential cause; it is usually unilateral, associated with microphthalmia, and occurs in otherwise healthy infants.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Coloboma:
Incorrect: Coloboma often appears as a keyhole-shaped defect of the iris (though it can also involve the retina, choroid, or optic disc) and is associated with several genetic conditions, such as trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and CHARGE syndrome. This patient has no dysmorphic features suggestive of those conditions, and the ophthalmologic findings noted are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
✅ Congenital rubella syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinoblastoma:
Incorrect: Patients with retinoblastoma present with strabismus, leukocoria, and an intraocular mass on fundoscopic exam. The lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Retinopathy of prematurity:
Incorrect: Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants (typically born before 32 weeks’ gestation), especially when risk factors are present (e.g., prolonged mechanical ventilation, hyperoxygenation), and is characterized by retinal neovascularization on fundoscopic examination. The lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Vitreous hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage is commonly associated with trauma, thrombocytopenia, or coagulopathy and is characterized by blood in the vitreous humor. In contrast, the blue-grey pupillary reflex and lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of right eye pain and swelling for one week. The parent reports the patient has been vigorously rubbing his eye stating, “It hurts.” The week before he had nasal congestion and rhinorrhea. The patient has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 106/62 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally. There is soft tissue swelling, erythema, and tenderness about the right orbit. The patient has difficulty opening the eye. The left eye is within normal limits. There is nasal congestion. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following would indicate this patient should be treated as an inpatient with intravenous antibiotics?

choices.text: Absence of pain with extraocular eye movements
Decreased activity level of the child

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and findings, consistent with either preseptal periorbital cellulitis or orbital cellulitis. This patient should have had visual acuity testing during the physical examination. Patients with periorbital cellulitis often have normal visual acuity, while patients with orbital cellulitis have blurred vision or reduced visual acuity. Altered visual acuity indicates that the patient should be treated with intravenous antibiotics and urgent ophthalmology consultation.

Periorbital cellulitis is caused by bacterial infection around the orbit. Orbital cellulitis is caused by an infection within the orbit. The relation of the infection to the orbital septum and the presence or absence of increased intraorbital pressure can differentiate orbital from periorbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis occurs posterior to the orbital septum and is associated with increased intraorbital pressure, while periorbital cellulitis occurs in the soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum and is not associated with increased intraorbital pressure.

Signs of increased intraorbital pressure that can be seen with orbital cellulitis include blurred vision, decreased visual acuity testing, chemosis, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and abnormal corneal light reflex. Additionally, patients with orbital cellulitis can have systemic signs of infection like fever and leukocytosis while patients with periorbital cellulitis rarely have these signs. Patients with orbital cellulitis require inpatient IV antibiotics to prevent complications that could lead to permanent vision loss

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased visual acuity testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Absence of pain with extraocular eye movements:
Incorrect: Pain with extraocular movements is a sign of orbital cellulitis for which patients should be hospitalized; however, if there is no pain, then periorbital cellulitis is more likely, which can be treated with outpatient antibiotics.
❌ Sinus tenderness:
Incorrect: Both periorbital and orbital cellulitis can result from extension from infection of the sinuses. Therefore, the presence of sinus tenderness would not help determine the diagnosis and need for intravenous antibiotics.
❌ Significant swelling of the eyelids:
Incorrect: Both periorbital and orbital cellulitis can result in significant swelling of the eyelids. Therefore, this would not help determine the diagnosis and the need for intravenous antibiotics.
❌ Decreased activity level of the child:
Incorrect: Both conditions can lead to decreased activity levels in children, this would not help distinguish between the two. However, if there is significant lethargy with signs of systemic infection this would be more consistent with orbital cellulitis with or without sepsis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of a “lazy eye.” Teachers have noticed the patient squinting at the blackboard for several weeks, and the child’s caregiver notes that the left eye now appears to be “looking inward” over the past several days. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the finding shown in the image below. The patient’s red reflexes are intact bilaterally. Visual acuity is 20/20 OD (right eye) and 20/40 OS (left eye). Corneal light reflection and a cover-uncover test demonstrate persistent ocular misalignment, and there is persistent deviation regardless of gaze direction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia (CC by 3.0)
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old patient presents with findings concerning for amblyopia. Examination reveals eye deviation on gross examination with persistent ocular misalignment on corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests. Additionally, there is consistent deviation regardless of gaze direction, which is consistent with a comitant tropia. The inward deviation of the eye indicates esotropia.        

Patients with true strabismic amblyopia have visible eye deviation on gross examination, whereas deprivation and refractive amblyopia do not. A complete eye examination with fundoscopy can identify a significant refractive error (refractive amblyopia) or reveal a visual obstruction (deprivation amblyopia).       

When strabismic amblyopia is suspected, corneal light reflection and cover-uncover testing should be performed. Ocular misalignment confirms true strabismus and warrants assessment of its consistency. If the deviation remains the same in all gaze directions, it is a comitant tropia and is classified by the direction of the deviation: inward deviation indicates esotropia, while outward deviation indicates exotropia. If the deviation varies with gaze direction, it indicates noncomitant tropia, for which the differential diagnosis includes CN III, CN IV, or CN VI palsy, which are distinguished by their characteristic patterns in gaze deviation.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudostrabismus:
Incorrect: Pseudostrabismus produces a false appearance of eye misalignment because of certain anatomic facial features. Both the corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests would be normal.  
✅ Esotropia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exotropia :
Incorrect: Exotropia refers to an outward deviation of the eye rather than the inward deviation seen here.  
❌ Cranial nerve (CN) VI palsy:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy can result in the appearance of esotropia; however, the ocular deviation associated with a pure CN VI palsy will vary with gaze direction.  
❌ Cranial nerve (CN) IV palsy:
Incorrect: Trochlear nerve (CN IV) palsy produces a vertical, upward ocular misalignment (hypertropia) that will vary with gaze direction.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of a newly noted squint. There is no history of pet exposure, fever, rash, seizures, trauma, or recent illness. The child was born at term, and prenatal history is unremarkable. Past medical and surgical histories are non-contributory. Family history is notable for osteosarcoma in the father. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination is notable for strabismus. No dysmorphic features are seen. Direct ophthalmoscopy reveals a white pupil on the right and a normal red reflex on the left. A whitish-gray retinal mass is seen on fundoscopic exam. Which of the following would confirm this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant with strabismus, unilateral leukocoria, an intraocular mass on examination, no history of pet exposure, and a family history of osteosarcoma most likely has retinoblastoma. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can confirm the diagnosis.

In a pediatric patient presenting with leukocoria, the first step is to determine whether an intraocular mass is present. If so, inquire about exposure to cat or dog feces and a history of geophagia (eating dirt), since these factors increase the risk of toxocariasis and ocular larva migrans. When those risk factors are absent, retinoblastoma should be strongly considered.

Retinoblastoma is the most common ocular tumor in children and typically presents with leukocoria in a child under three years of age. History may reveal strabismus or visual changes. A family history of retinoblastoma or related tumors such as osteosarcoma reflects a germline RB1 gene mutation. Clinical findings may include one or more creamy or whitish-gray retinal masses, orbital inflammation, blood in the anterior chamber (hyphema), retinal detachment, or vitreous inflammation. Once suspected, orbital ultrasound or MRI confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating an intraocular mass with calcifications and assessing for optic nerve involvement or extraocular spread.

Option Analysis

❌ Slit-lamp examination  :
Incorrect: A slit-lamp evaluates anterior eye structures, including the cornea and lens, and is commonly used to diagnose cataracts, keratitis, and uveitis. Without specialized lenses, it is less effective for assessing the posterior segment. In suspected retinoblastoma, cross-sectional imaging (e.g. MRI) provides a more reliable evaluation.
❌ ELISA test for Toxocara canis:
Incorrect: Toxocara canis causes ocular larva migrans (OLM), which can present with an intraocular mass in patients with exposure to dog feces. In this case, however, an intraocular mass coupled with a positive family history and no pet exposure makes retinoblastoma far more likely. Orbital MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Karyotype:
Incorrect: Standard karyotyping can identify chromosomal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 21, trisomy 18), which can be associated with cataracts. However, an intraocular mass coupled with a family history of osteosarcoma are concerning for retinoblastoma. Potential point mutations or small deletions in the RB1 gene would not be detected on karyotyping.
✅ Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rubella IgG antibodies:
Incorrect: Congenital rubella infection can lead to cataracts, which are lens opacities rather than an intraocular mass. The history and findings in this case are more consistent with retinoblastoma, which is best evaluated by orbital MRI.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by a parent for evaluation of visual disturbance. The parent reports noticing the child has been squinting and tilting his head to the right when watching TV for the past several weeks. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Red reflexes are intact bilaterally. Visual acuity is 20/60 OD (right eye) and 20/20 OS (left eye). Examination reveals no evidence of eye deviation. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old patient presents with signs of amblyopia. Because there is no evidence of eye deviation on history or gross examination, refractive or deprivation amblyopia is most likely. The next diagnostic step is to perform a complete eye examination including fundoscopy.        

True strabismic amblyopia will present with eye deviation based on history and/or gross examination. These patients warrant assessment with corneal light reflection and a cover-uncover testing. If these tests reveal no ocular misalignment, pseudostrabismus is likely. In contrast, persistent ocular misalignment is consistent with true strabismus and should prompt evaluation for the consistency of the misalignment.        

When there is no clear deviation but amblyopia is suspected, the workup should distinguish between obstruction and refractive error with a complete eye examination, including fundoscopy. Deprivation amblyopia typically demonstrates a visual obstruction on examination, such as an ocular mass, vitreous hemorrhage, hemangioma, or corneal or lens opacity. Refractive amblyopia is confirmed by identifying a significant refractive error.    

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain :
Incorrect: MRI is generally not indicated in the workup of strabismus or amblyopia. It can be considered if there is a focal neurologic deficit or papilledema on fundoscopic exam. Because this patient has no evidence of eye deviation, refractive or deprivation amblyopia is suspected. The next step is a complete eye examination with fundoscopy. 
✅ Fundoscopic examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the brain :
Incorrect: CT is generally not indicated in the workup of strabismus or amblyopia. It can be considered if there is a focal neurologic deficit or papilledema on fundoscopic exam. Because this patient has no evidence of eye deviation, refractive or deprivation amblyopia is suspected. The next step is a complete eye examination with fundoscopy. 
❌ Intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement:
Incorrect: An IOP measurement is used to evaluate for glaucoma. It does not provide useful information in the work up of strabismus or amblyopia. 
❌ Lumbar puncture :
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is indicated for suspected meningitis, which can cause a comitant tropia (e.g., esotropia, exotropia). However, this would cause eye deviation, which is absent here. The absence of deviation suggests refractive or deprivation amblyopia, warranting a complete eye examination with fundoscopy.

questions.text: A 4-week-old premature infant born at 28 weeks’ gestation, with a birth weight of 900 grams, is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). The pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia and a positive Group B Streptococcus (GBS) test, for which treatment was given. The infant required intubation at birth, received two doses of surfactant, and remained on mechanical ventilation with 100% oxygen concentrations for three weeks. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 82/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on a nasal cannula delivering 60% FiO<sub>2</sub>. On physical examination, the infant appears active. The head is normocephalic with an open, soft anterior fontanelle. Cardiopulmonary examination shows normal heart sounds without murmurs and clear breath sounds bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and non-distended with normal bowel sounds. Extremities are symmetric with normal tone and movement. Ophthalmologic examination reveals a white pupillary reflex without lens opacity. Fundoscopy shows vitreous haze and neovascularization in both eyes, without intraocular masses or hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this infant's ophthalmologic findings?
questions.solution:
This preterm, low-birth weight neonate with history of prolonged mechanical ventilation and hyperoxygenation presents with bilateral leukocoria and retinal neovascularization. These features support a diagnosis of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), the most common cause of severe visual impairment in children. Of the answer choices given, prematurity is the most significant risk factor.

In any preterm infant with leukocoria, ROP should be strongly considered. This disorder involves uncontrolled retinal vascular and capillary proliferation, affecting premature infants who receive supplemental oxygen therapy. A dilated fundus exam should be performed on all infants born at or before 30 weeks’ gestation and those weighing ≤1500 grams. Screening should begin at 4 weeks’ postnatal age or at a corrected gestational age of 30 to 31 weeks. Typical findings include a bilateral, symmetric white reflex, cloudy vitreous, neovascularization of the retina, and fibrous proliferation behind the lens.

When evaluating a pediatric patient with leukocoria, obtain a thorough history followed by a dilated fundoscopic and slit-lamp examination. A history of prematurity suggests ROP, in which leukocoria is due to retinal detachment.
